12.1 Distributor shall have the option to return to Cisco, for credit, up [*****] of the dollar value of Products from the Wholesale Price List (or, if
no Wholesale Price Lists exists for Distributor's Territory, then the applicable price list)
shipped to Distributor, net of credits, less returns to Cisco, in the preceding [*****] period (the "Balancing Cap") of the
preceding Cisco fiscal quarter. The above-referenced cap shall be determined based on all Product purchases made under
this Agreement. The responsibility to manage the Balancing Cap shall rest solely upon Distributor. Distributor shall be
entitled to return Product once per quarter, provided such returns do not exceed the Balancing Cap. "Dead on Arrival"
and Obsolete Products returned pursuant to Section 13 of this Agreement shall be excluded from calculation of the
Balancing Cap. Cisco shall credit Distributor's account in the amount of the price paid by Distributor therefore, less any
price protection credits issued to Distributor related to the Product returned (the "Return Credit").
perturbation.changed_text:
12.1 Distributor shall have the option to return to Cisco, for credit, Products shipped to Distributor. The responsibility to manage returns shall rest solely upon Distributor. Distributor shall be
entitled to return Product once per quarter. "Dead on Arrival"
and Obsolete Products returned pursuant to Section 13 of this Agreement shall be excluded from calculation of Product returns. Cisco shall credit Distributor's account in the amount of the price paid by Distributor.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the "Balancing Cap" clause and the specifics of Wholesale Price List, the section now lacks a clearly defined limit or valuation method for returns. The term 'Balancing Cap' is still referenced in relation to dead on arrival products, creating an inconsistency. This omission creates uncertainty in enforcement, as there's no longer a set method to calculate return credit value, making the process ambiguous.

21.1 In connection with the sale or distribution of Cisco Products or Services, or otherwise in carrying out its obligations under this Agreement,
Distributor represents and warrants the following:
(a) Distributor will comply with all country, federal, state and local laws, ordinances, codes, regulations, rules, policies and procedures, Including,
without limitation, all anti-corruption laws, Including, the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (Applicable Laws). Distributor can find more
information about the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act at the following URL: http://www.usdoj.gov/criminal/fraud/docs/dojdocb.html, or by
contacting publicsectorcompllance@cisco.com.
(b) Distributor shall not take any action or permit or authorize any action in violation of the Applicable Laws;
perturbation.changed_text:
21.1 In connection with the sale or distribution of Cisco Products or Services, or otherwise in carrying out its obligations under this Agreement,
Distributor represents and warrants the following:
(a) Distributor will comply with all country, federal, state and local laws, ordinances, codes, regulations, rules, policies and procedures.
(b) Distributor shall not take any action or permit or authorize any action in violation of the Applicable Laws;
perturbation.explanation: By removing the specific inclusion of anti-corruption laws and the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (FCPA) from clause (a), and the URL for more information, the contract becomes ambiguous regarding the distributor's obligations related to anti-corruption. While (b) states compliance with 'Applicable Laws', the explicit reference is removed, making it less clear that anti-corruption measures are a critical part of compliance. This change reduces legal certainty in enforcing anti-corruption measures.
